metadata.case_name: Nagpur Electric Light and Power Co. Ltd. v. Shreepathi Rao

facts.text: The respondent joined the service of the Company as a typist on a salary of Rs. 30 per month in July, 1936.
The respondent rose in rank and was appointed Deputy Head Clerk in 1947 in the grade of Rs. 120-10-225. Since 1952 he has been receiving a basic salary of Rs. 245 per month.

On November 28, 1955, an explanation was called for from the respondent with regard to the issue of certain bills to high tension consumers without having certain numbers printed at the back of the bills.
The respondent submitted his explanation on November 29, 1955, marking a copy thereof to one of the directors of the Company.
On December 2, 1955, the respondent was asked to explain why he marked a copy of his explanation to one of the directors.
The respondent submitted an explanation in respect of this matter on December 2, 1955.

On December 2, 1955, the respondent was asked to explain as to how and why certain double adjustments had been made in the accounts of 1954 relating to the consumers department, alleging Rs. 1,05,894-7-7 deducted twice.
The respondent submitted an explanation on December 3, 1955, stating the charge was vague and that after 1949 he was not concerned with preparation of summaries and annual statements.
On December 5, 1955, an order of suspension was made against the respondent, to take immediate effect pending investigation.
On December 7, 1955, a memorandum terminating services effective January 31, 1956 under Standing Order 16(1), stating Managing Director satisfied not in interests to disclose reasons.
On December 19, 1955, notice served on Company stating suspension and termination illegal, demand withdrawal and reinstatement within 24 hours.
On December 26, 1955, Company replied denying allegations, no desire to discuss.
On January 2, 1956, respondent filed petition under Art. 226 in Nagpur High Court praying to quash suspension and termination orders.
High Court single Judge on April 14, 1956 dismissed petition on preliminary objections: Standing Orders not applicable, contractual relationship, sue for damages.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 66 of 1956 allowed by Division Bench on September 26, 1956: Standing Orders not apply, governed by local Act, termination without authority, quashed orders, back wages.
Appellants obtained special leave from Supreme Court.
Standing Orders approved under Central Act and local Act, came into force November 14, 1951.
No ticket issued to respondent, his name and ticket number not in departmental muster.
Company paid salary from suspension to January 31, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Standing Orders of the Company apply to the respondent.
Whether the termination of service was in accordance with Standing Order 16(1).
Scope of Art. 226 jurisdiction for wrongful dismissal by private employer.

petitioner_arguments.text: Standing Orders apply to respondent; termination in accordance with Standing Order 16(1). Inclusion of name and ticket number not essential characteristic of employee.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Standing Order 2(a), Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946; C.P. and Berar Act XXIII of 1947

petitioner_arguments.text: If Standing Orders do not apply, ordinary law of master and servant applies; remedy is suit for damages.
Even if wrongful dismissal, no jurisdiction under Art. 226 against private employer.

respondent_arguments.text: Standing Orders do not apply as respondent not issued ticket, name and ticket number not in departmental muster; essential characteristic missing.
Company breached s.30 local Act by not making Standing Orders for employees like him without tickets.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.30 C.P. and Berar Act XXIII of 1947

respondent_arguments.text: Suspension violated Standing Order 18(e); merits need decision.

court_reasoning.text: Standing Orders distinguish between 'employees' (larger group: all persons employed in specified departments) and 'workmen' (smaller group declared by management, with tickets). Inclusion of ticket numbers not essential for employees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All workmen are employees, but not vice versa; some employees have no tickets (e.g., clerical staff).

court_reasoning.text: Standing Order 16 applies to all employees; termination complied with one month's notice, reasons not disclosed as permitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No penalty under Standing Order 18 imposed; salary paid during suspension.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'whose names and ticket numbers are included in the departmental musters' read as 'if any'; applies only where tickets issued, to comply with statutory obligation under s.30 local Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Construction avoids breach of statutory duty imposing criminal liability.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide Art.226 scope as Standing Orders apply and termination valid.

holdings.text: Standing Orders apply to respondent as employee; definition in SO 2(a) does not require ticket for all employees.
Termination valid under SO 16(1); no violation of SO 18.

precedents_cited.case_name: Courts v. The Kent Waterworks Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle: In statutes, provisions inapplicable to certain persons (e.g., corporations unable to enter recognizance) do not exclude them from benefits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Perumal Goundan v. The Thirumalarayapuram Jananukoola Dhanasekhara Sangha Nidhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation to O. XXXIII r.1 CPC: 'Necessary wearing apparel' not excluding companies without apparel from pauper suits.

precedents_cited.case_name: D. C. Dungore v. S. S. Dandige
precedents_cited.citation: Misc. Petition No. 134 of 1954 (Nagpur High Court, Sep 23, 1955)
precedents_cited.relevance: Company took different stand earlier, but no estoppel in statutory construction; that employee not within Act.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946 (XX of 1946)
statutes_cited.relevance: Approval of Standing Orders; definition of workman; matters like termination.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 (XXIII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Approval and amendment of Standing Orders; definition of employee; statutory obligation to make SOs for all employees.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of High Court Division Bench dated September 26, 1956 set aside; respondent's writ petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: 'employees means all persons... employed in the Office or Mains Department... whose names and ticket numbers are included in the departmental musters.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key definition in Standing Order 2(a) interpreted.

key_quotes.text: The essential content of the definition of an employee is employment in the Office, Mains Department, etc., of the Company... and that of a workman the necessary declaration by the Company.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of holding on applicability of Standing Orders.

key_quotes.text: We are not unmindful of the principle that... every word occurring therein must be given its proper meaning... But even a definition clause must derive its meaning from the context.
key_quotes.speaker: court
